docs.lead_paragraph: A top housing official warned yesterday that New York City's new lead-paint law may raise operating costs for landlords, contributing to an anticipated increase in rents for rent-stabilized apartments. Harold M. Shultz, special counsel to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, told members of the city's Rent Guidelines Board that it was impossible to determine just how much costs would go up, since the new law is not scheduled to go into effect until August, and two suits have also been filed challenging the law.

headline.main: Lead-Paint Law May Add To Rent Increase, Aide Says

docs.abstract: Harold M Shultz, special counsel to New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, warns that city's new lead-paint law may raise operating costs for landlords, contributing to anticipated increase in rents for rent-stabilized apartments (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Private hospitals in New York City have fallen more than $100 million behind on payments to employee benefit and pension funds in recent years, deepening the hospitals' money woes and threatening thousands of workers with the loss of health insurance and other benefits. The arrears have roughly doubled since the start of 2003, and about three dozen hospitals and nursing homes are now listed by the funds as delinquent on payments. ''This is absolutely the worst situation we've seen, both in terms of the dollars and the number of institutions involved,'' said Mitra Behroozi, executive director of the funds, separate entities that are controlled jointly by the hospitals and the health workers' union.

headline.main: Benefit Funds Owed Millions By Hospitals

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of part-time New York University professors voted to strike next Wednesday if the university's administration does not give them a contract they consider fair, Scott Sommer, a union representative, said last night. In a mail vote, 91.4 percent of the university's adjunct professors who voted, chose to strike for higher wages and for health insurance and job security, Mr. Sommer said. They have been negotiating with the university for 18 months but have not been able to come to an agreement, Mr. Sommer said. He said there were 2,300 adjunct professors at the university in the 2002-03 academic year. A university spokesman could not be reached for comment after the vote results were tallied late last night. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. Adjuncts Set Strike Deadline

docs.abstract: New York State Health Dept plan to spend more than $45 million on antismoking programs this year, up from $31 million last year (S)

byline.original: By Sabrina Tavernise (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: The recent decision by Abbott Laboratories to quintuple the price of its crucial AIDS drug Norvir will be at the center of a federal hearing today in which AIDS groups and consumer advocates plan to argue that the government should begin allowing the import of cheaper drugs. The hearing, which will be conducted by the Department of Health and Human Services, is a result of last fall's Medicare drug legislation, in which Congress called for a general inquiry into the import question. But the escalating protest over Norvir, whose average annual dosage cost rose to about $7,800 in January from $1,500, has suddenly given the import issue unexpected urgency.

headline.main: Price of AIDS Drug Intensifies Debate On Legal Imports

docs.abstract: Recent decision by Abbott Laboratories to quintuple price of its crucial AIDS drug Norvir will be at center of Federal Health and Human Servicers hearing in which AIDS groups and consumer advocates plan to argue that government should begin allowing import of cheaper drugs; hearing is result of last fall's Medicare drug legislation, in which Congress called for general inquiry into import question; but escalating protest over Norvir, whose average annual dosage cost rose to about $7,800 in January from $1,500, has suddenly given import issue unexpected urgency; table shows how costs for various prescription drugs in US exceed those in other industrial countries; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. May Back Israel Right To Keep Some Settlements President Bush is planning to issue a declaration during Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's visit to the White House today that aides say will recognize Israel's right to retain some Jewish settlements in the West Bank when its future boundaries are negotiated with the Palestinians. The declaration would represent a subtle but substantial shift in policy. A1 U.S. Pressure on Iraqi Cleric A 2,500-strong American force backed by tanks and artillery took up positions outside Najaf as a rebel Shiite cleric, Moktada al-Sadr, resisted demands from the American occupation authority and fellow Shiite clerics that he disband a militia that has challenged American authority. docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly 20 years, Dr. Bruce E. Murphy, a cardiologist and the son of a Baptist minister, has admitted patients to hospitals operated by Baptist Health, the dominant hospital system in Little Rock, Ark. Then in February, he received a letter from Baptist Health saying it might end his hospital privileges. Dr. Murphy recalls thinking, ''It's not a very Christian thing to do, is it?''

headline.main: Barred as Rivals, Doctors See Some Hospitals in Court

docs.abstract: Growing number of doctors are suing hospitals for right to practice at community hospitals while setting up separate facilities for specific ailments; Baptist Health in Little Rock, Ark, is warning Little Rock's cardiologists that to invest in competing hospital could mean no longer treating patients at Baptist Health hospital after seven years of watching Arkansas Heart Hospital vie for patients; cardiologists have sued in state court to stop Baptist Health from carrying out threat; doctors in Columbus, Ohio, who have put money into new orthopedic hospital have lost right to practice at hospitals in OhioHealth network; similar fights are brewing elsewhere, as doctors pursue business strategies that put them in competition with community hospitals; hospitals argue that doctors are threatening their viability by skimming off most profitable cases, while leaving hospitals with too many of patients least able to pay their bills or those whose complicated conditions run up high expenses; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration is warning doctors that they can be fined or expelled from the Medicare program if they charge patients extra for providing a deluxe version of services already covered by Medicare. Some doctors, seeking extra income, offer special services and amenities to patients who pay added fees or retainers. The fees range from $500 a year for an individual to $20,000 or more for a family.

headline.main: U.S. Warns About Care Doctors Offer For Extra Fees

docs.abstract: Bush administration warns doctors that they can be fined or expelled from Medicare program if they charge patients extra for providing deluxe version of services already covered by Medicare; some doctors offer special services to patients who pay additional fees and retainers ranging from $500 to $20,000 annually, which gives them prime access and customized services, but often ends up excluding other patients who cannot afford fees (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH new government-endorsed drug discount cards becoming available June 1, many Medicare recipients are facing a difficult task in comparison shopping. Twenty-eight companies have been approved by the federal government to market the cards, which should lower prescription drug costs by 10 to 25 percent. The discount cards are a stopgap, part of the broad Medicare bill enacted in December that, among other measures, provides a comprehensive, federally subsidized Medicare drug benefit starting in 2006.

headline.main: Discount Drug Cards Are Coming: It's Time to Do Your Homework

docs.abstract: Many Medicare recipients are facing difficult task in comparison shopping for new government-endorsed drug discount cards that will be available June 1; government has approved 28 companies to market cards, which should cut prescription drug costs by 10 to 25 percent; cards are stopgap until comprehensive subsidized Medicare drug benefit starts in 2006; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 10 years since the federal law eliminating mandatory retirement took effect, universities have faced a conundrum: namely, how to encourage senior professors to step aside to make room for younger instructors. At institutions like Yale University, where senior faculty enjoy status and economic success unmatched by most of their academic peers, it can be particularly difficult to make emeriti out of perfectly happy, if graying, instructors. So Yale has begun to approach this delicate issue from a new perspective, encouraging professors to retire, but stick around.

headline.main: A Home Away From Home Keeps Old Scholars Happy

docs.abstract: Yale University, where high status and economic success make senior faculty loath to retire, has opened center for its retired professors and administrators; center director, Dr Bernard Lytton, says goal is to bring emeriti back into mainstream life of university; deputy provost Charles Long says Yale seeks to make retirement as inviting as possible; center's participants are just beginning to hatch ideas about how best to stay involved with campus; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IN the 10 years since the federal law eliminating mandatory retirement took effect, universities have faced a conundrum: namely, how to encourage senior professors to step aside to make room for younger instructors.    At institutions like Yale...

docs.lead_paragraph: THOUGH they have surfaced only fleetingly in the opening rounds of the presidential campaign, some of the deepest and most explosive divisions between George W. Bush and John F. Kerry are over the future of retirement. The issues are so politically treacherous and abstract that both candidates have shied away from them in public -- an easy thing to do when the headlines have been dominated by Iraq, the 9/11 commission and jobs.
docs.abstract: Some of deepest and most explosive divisions between George W Bush and John F Kerry, issues so politically treacherous and abstract that both candidates have shied away from them in public, are over future of retirement; much of intensely partisan war is raging over whether Americans should save for old age collectively as nation, or as individuals through private savings and investments; Democrats hope to tie traditional distrust of older Americans for proposals that seem to threaten Social Security and Medicare to broader economic anxieties of younger workers; Republicans are arguing that two giant entitlement programs will be overwhelmed by soaring costs as baby boomers reach retirement age; are building case for partially replacing Social Security with new system of private accounts; photos (M)
